inputs.text: But finding it wasn't enough, was it?
[excited] Oh NO, finding it was just the beginning. Then came the engineering phase, and THIS is where Cosmos completely blew my mind.

For four days straight, I watched him collect materials. Coconut shell halves, smooth stones, broken coral fragments, even a bottle cap someone had littered. [thoughtful] He'd carry three, sometimes FOUR objects at once in his arms, bring them back, and arrange them with this... obsessive precision.

[excited] Not just building - DESIGNING. Every shell was tested for fit. Every stone was positioned to create defensive barriers while maintaining escape routes. [inhales] And here's the crazy part: one day I watched him pick up a rock, examine it with his suckers - which can taste and feel simultaneously, by the way - rotate it 180 degrees, and place it in a completely different location. [pause] Then he stepped back and LOOKED at his work.

[laughs] He revised his design! My research partner surfaced next to me and through our regulators she managed to say: [whispers dramatically] 'Did that octopus just edit his architecture?' [normal voice] And yes. Yes, he did.
